uncertainties: Authoritative reviews indicate caffeine itself has not been linked to clinically apparent liver injury; therefore mechanistic scoring reflects low intrinsic hepatotoxic liability rather than an established DILI phenotype.
Reports of liver injury with energy drinks are confounded by multi-ingredient formulations (e.g., vitamins/other additives); attribution to caffeine alone is uncertain.

At extreme/toxic systemic exposures, secondary hepatic hypoxia/ischemic-like injury patterns have been described in energy-drink contexts, but mechanism is not clearly direct hepatocyte toxicity from caffeine.
